text: Most of my bots bet within an hour of a race starting. So they use relatively little capital. The longer term bots bet when there is over an hour left. I consider those long term and they use more capital as there are lots more events.

text: <@U017A7TRF6E> - in Australia we call these "bowler" accounts. Usually people go through their extended family and friends, Wouldn't be necessary if we didn't import the practice from the UK of severely limiting accounts because you are winning. Has been a recent trend (last 10 years) as independent Australian bookies have been bought out by UK corporates

text:
Me - full time PLC programmer for industrial machinery, M.O.D. ships, etc. Spare time Betfair botter, although "spare" time is something I rarely have which makes development very slow. Never _quite_ got to the point where consistent profits are big enough to live off. Having said that, I bought my house without a mortgage, although I do also invest in managed stock funds as well as play Betfair. Strangely, I'm not too bothered if a stock fund value drops by a few grand (if anything, I see that as an opportunity to invest more) but losing the same amount on Betfair really hurts.

Regarding market efficiency, my opinion is that as long as the prices are fluctuating, it's NOT efficient.

elements.text: Me - full time PLC programmer for industrial machinery, M.O.D. ships, etc. Spare time Betfair botter, although "spare" time is something I rarely have which makes development very slow. Never
quite

got to the point where consistent profits are big enough to live off. Having said that, I bought my house without a mortgage, although I do also invest in managed stock funds as well as play Betfair. Strangely, I'm not too bothered if a stock fund value drops by a few grand (if anything, I see that as an opportunity to invest more) but losing the same amount on Betfair really hurts.

Regarding market efficiency, my opinion is that as long as the prices are fluctuating, it's NOT efficient.

text: I think that last point is very relevant ("as long as the prices are fluctuating, it's NOT efficient"). The market can't be right if the price is changing rapidly but the "real" probabilities are reasonably constant

elements.text: I think that last point is very relevant ("as long as the prices are fluctuating, it's NOT efficient"). The market can't be right if the price is changing rapidly but the "real" probabilities are reasonably constant

text: But that supposes you are betting using a calculated probability and not on price movements

elements.text: But that supposes you are betting using a calculated probability and not on price movements
